text.p: These are the leading stories in the Belgrade press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified them nor does it vouch for their accuracy.
- There will be no devaluation of the dinar and we will continue to pursue the policy of maintaining a stable currency and prices next year, says Yugoslav President Zoran Lilic.

- Succession talks on the former Yugoslavia end in Brussels without agreement. The former Yugoslav republics will conduct separate talks with mediator Sir Arthur Watts and then hold another plenary meeting before the end of year.
- Yugoslavia asks for the restoration of its pre-sanctions status in the European Union and an equal position with other ex-Yugoslav republics, says Yugoslav Chamber of Economy President in Sweden.
- Blackout for the nation's run-off local elections starts at midnight Thursday.
- A MiG-21 crashed at military Batajnica airfield in Belgrade.

- Opposition coalition Zajedno accuses the ruling Socialists of distributing forged pamphlets about rifts within the coalition and threatening elderly voters with pension cuts if they vote for the opposition.

- The scheduled visit of a World Bank delegation on November 19 to Belgrade should not be given excessive importance. Commentary says at best the delegation could announce that the bank intends to prepare for renewal of contacts with Yugoslavia.
- Serbian entrepreneurs extend support to the ministry for private enterprise and ask minister Radoje Djukic to withdraw his resignation.
- Newly elected Montenegrin parliament to hold its first session on November 18.
- Yugoslavia will soon introduce an anti-dumping law in the metal sector, says Serbian industry minister Oskar Fodor.

- The price of the basket of food and drink for a four-member family has grown by 4.8 percent in October on the previous month while registered inflation reached 1.4 percent, showing that not all prices have stabilised. -- Belgrade Newsroom, 381 11 222 4254
